sn55.27:4.2: Now at that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn55.27:4.5: and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
sn55.27:4.6: ‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn55.27:4.7: He bows with his head to your feet.’
sn55.27:4.9: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of compassion.’”
sn55.27:5.1: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Anāthapiṇḍika asked.
sn55.27:6.1: Then Venerable Ānanda got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the home of the householder Anāthapiṇḍika.
sn55.27:6.2: He sat down on the indicated seat
sn55.27:6.4: “Householder, I hope you’re coping; I hope you’re getting better. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing; that it’s fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn55.27:6.7: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright.
sn55.27:6.8: The pain is terrible and growing, not fading,
sn55.27:6.9: its growing, not fading, is apparent.”
sn55.27:7.1: “Householder, when an uneducated ordinary person has four things, they’re frightened and terrified, and fear what awaits them after death.
sn55.27:7.3: Firstly, an uneducated ordinary person distrusts the Buddha.
sn55.27:7.4: Seeing in themselves that distrust of the Buddha, they’re frightened and terrified, and fear what awaits them after death.
sn55.27:8.1: Furthermore, an uneducated ordinary person distrusts the teaching …
sn55.27:10.1: Furthermore, an uneducated ordinary person has unethical conduct.
sn55.27:10.2: Seeing in themselves that unethical conduct, they’re frightened and terrified, and fear what awaits them after death.
sn55.27:10.3: When an uneducated ordinary person has these four things, they’re frightened and terrified, and fear what awaits them after death.
sn55.27:11.1: When an educated noble disciple has four things, they’re not frightened or terrified, and don’t fear what awaits them after death.
sn55.27:11.3: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.27:11.6: Seeing in themselves that experiential confidence in the Buddha, they’re not frightened or terrified, and don’t fear what awaits them after death.
sn55.27:12.1: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Dharma …
sn55.27:14.1: Furthermore, a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, unflawed, unblemished, untainted, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to samādhi.
sn55.27:14.3: Seeing in themselves that ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, they’re not frightened or terrified, and don’t fear what awaits them after death.
sn55.27:14.4: When an educated noble disciple has these four things, they’re not frightened or terrified, and don’t fear what awaits them after death.”
sn55.27:15.3: For I have experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.27:15.10: And of the training rules appropriate for laypeople taught by the Buddha, I don’t see any that I have broken.”
sn55.27:15.12: You have declared the fruit of stream-entry.”
